message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including sharp chest pain that worsens with deep inspiration and coughing, along with an ECG revealing ST elevations and depressions in aVR and V1, suggest pericarditis. Treatment for pericarditis includes increasing the dose of aspirin. Heparin infusion is used for acute coronary syndrome or pulmonary embolism, nitroglycerin is used for angina, and CT angiography is not necessary for diagnosis and treatment of pericarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest acute pericarditis, which can occur following a myocardial infarction. Elevated ECG suggests that the pericarditis may be due to Dressler syndrome. Treatment options include NSAIDs or colchicine, but since the patient is already on aspirin, increasing the dose would be the most appropriate first step. Heparin infusion and nitroglycerin are not indicated in this case, and CT angiography is not useful for diagnosis of pericarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, examination findings and ECG suggest acute pericarditis. Treatment usually involves NSAIDs, including aspirin. Heparin would be appropriate for a pulmonary embolism or acute coronary syndrome, but not for pericarditis. Nitroglycerin would not be effective for pericarditis. CT angiography would not be necessary for pericarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and ECG findings suggest acute pericarditis, which can be caused by recent cardiac catheterization. Treatment involves nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), with aspirin being the first-line agent. Heparin infusion is not necessary unless there is evidence of concurrent thromboembolism. Nitroglycerin is used to treat angina, which is not the primary concern in this case. CT angiography is not necessary for diagnosis of pericarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest acute pericarditis, which is also supported by the high-pitched scratching sound and ECG findings. The most appropriate treatment would be to increase the dose of aspirin, which has anti-inflammatory properties and can help reduce inflammation in the pericardium. Heparin is not indicated unless there is evidence of thrombus formation, nitroglycerin is not indicated in pericarditis, and CT angiography is not necessary for diagnosis or management of pericarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest pericarditis, which can occur as a complication after a heart attack. Aspirin is the first-line medication for treating pericarditis, as it helps with inflammation and pain. Heparin is not used to treat pericarditis. Nitroglycerin may be used for chest pain related to heart attack, but not pericarditis. CT angiography is not necessary for this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including sharp chest pain that worsens with deep breathing and coughing, as well as ST elevations on ECG, suggest pericarditis. The most appropriate treatment for pericarditis is to increase the dose of aspirin to reduce inflammation. Heparin infusion is not indicated and nitroglycerin and CT angiography are not appropriate for treating pericarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and ECG findings suggest acute pericarditis. Among the options, increasing the aspirin dose is the most appropriate treatment for acute pericarditis. Heparin may be used for pulmonary embolism, nitroglycerin for angina, and CT angiography may be useful for diagnosing pulmonary embolism or aortic dissection, but these conditions are not the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, such as sharp chest pain that worsens with deep inspiration and coughing, as well as high-pitched scratching sound during cardiac examination, suggest pericarditis. The ECG findings of diffuse ST elevations and ST depression in aVR and V1 are consistent with pericarditis. Aspirin is the most appropriate treatment for pericarditis. Starting heparin infusion is not indicated as there is no evidence of thrombus or embolism. Nitroglycerin is not indicated for pericarditis. Performing CT angiography is not necessary as the echocardiography showed no abnormalities.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms indicate acute pericarditis, which is confirmed by the high-pitched scratching sound heard during cardiac examination and the ECG showing diffuse ST elevations. The most appropriate treatment is to increase the dose of aspirin, which is a first-line therapy for acute pericarditis. Heparin infusion and nitroglycerin are not indicated in the treatment of acute pericarditis. CT angiography is not needed for diagnosis of acute pericarditis.
